column1: The city—which was the original London—is the most ancient. It was founded long before the days of the Romans; so long
column3: that its origin is wholly unknown. Nor is any thing known in respect to the derivation or meaning of the name. In regard to Westminster
column4: the name is known to come from the word minster
column5: which means cathedral—a cathedral church having been built there at a very early period
column7: lying west of London as it did
column8: was called the West Minster. This church passed through a great variety of mutations during the lapse of successive centuries
column15: times and ways without number. It is represented in the present age by the venerable monumental pile—the burial-place of the ancient kings
column16: and of the most distinguished nobles
column18: and statesmen of the English monarchy—known through all the world as Westminster Abbey.
